HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 7, 1929
JUNE WEEK DRAWING
TO BE HELD FRIDAY
Friday at 12.45 the June
Week Drawing will be held in
front of the barn. This drawing has taken the place of the
traditional tag week held in
former years. Instead of giving a dollar and receiving no
return as formerly, the stu.dents are asked for only twen-.
tyzfive cents and at the same
time obtain a chance on a suit
or ,topcoat. However, the
ticket sale is not progressing
as well as might be expected
under these conditions and
better support is urged by the.
June Week Committee.

MARYLAND TICKETS
NOW ON SALE
Announcement was made
today by Henry Iddins, Business Manager of Athletics,
that from now on reserved
tickets for the Hopkins-Maryland lacrosse game at the Stadium on May 25th could be
procured at either the Treasurer's Office in Remsen Hall,
or from Mr. Myers at the Post
Office. A payment of 50c in
addition to the athletic card
will be necessary to get these
tickets.

THE

FIVE YEAR MAN
recently been a considerable amount of agitation on
the campus in favor of permitting graduate students or New,
Plan students in their fifth year of residence to participate in student activities. We are flatly opposed to any such proposition.
Extra-curricular activities are essentially for the undergraduate
and for him alone. To allow graduate students to head non-athletic
activities is to allow them to usurp the places rightfully belonging to
others. Furthermore, this practice would keep men from onouncing
their candidacy for staff' positions. A freshman would argue, and
rightfully so, that there would be no advantage in trying out for a
publication if there happened to be two or three men in their sophomore year already on the staff who meant to stay at college five years.'
For he would have no chance of earning a major board of control
position. In his senior year he would he outranked by these men
in their fifth year of residence.
The case of men in their first or second year of the New Plan
is entirely different. They are on a par with their fellows, not having the advantage ?ff. the extra year. But as soon as their fourth
year of residence is completed, they should automatically cease to be
eligible for Board of Control positions. , Let them gracefully yield
their place to therising college generation.
, This stand applies not only to' men who have Completed four
years at Johns Hopkins, but to those who have spent .part of their
allotted time elsewhere. Although it be unjust, it is a recognized •
fact that an upperclassman receives more consideration from the incumbents, and less difficulty in attaining a staff position than a fresh'
man. He is not compelled to, go through the long period of trial
and training to which the yearlings are subjected. Since he is given
preferential treatment as a candidate, he should accept the fact that
it will be more difficult for him to attain the, heights in his 'chosen
activity.
We do not think that thc activities will suffer greatly, if the five"
year man is prohibited from leading them. If he is a man of unusual ability he will have attained his major position in the four years
at his disposal. If he is not unusually capable there will be someone
in the senior class equally as well qualified to guide the destinies of
the activity as he.

EDITORIALS

S-LETTER, MAY 7, 1929

Pic*:
I smcfke and dream, and dream until
I get a plot, and get a thrill.
I am in the writing game, you see;
And the pipe-dreams softly bring to me
Scenes of carnage where the red blood
ran,.
And the dreams all come from a bright
Blue can.
It's just a can of Edgeworth-cutFragrant as flowers-sweet as Luut;
Of all Fate's kindly gifts to man
Is this gift of dreams from the bright
Blue can.
I sit me down at eve, to smoke;
And soon am wrapped in a magic cloak;
It has banished trouble, it has banished pain,
And the sad old world is young again.
J. H. Rockwell
Midland, Michigan.

THE

FIVE YEAR MAN
recently been a considerable amount of agitation on
the campus in favor of permitting graduate students or New,
Plan students in their fifth year of residence to participate in student activities. We are flatly opposed to any such proposition.
Extra-curricular activities are essentially for the undergraduate
and for him alone. To allow graduate students to head non-athletic
activities is to allow them to usurp the places rightfully belonging to
others. Furthermore, this practice would keep men from onouncing
their candidacy for staff' positions. A freshman would argue, and
rightfully so, that there would be no advantage in trying out for a
publication if there happened to be two or three men in their sophomore year already on the staff who meant to stay at college five years.'
For he would have no chance of earning a major board of control
position. In his senior year he would he outranked by these men
in their fifth year of residence.
The case of men in their first or second year of the New Plan
is entirely different. They are on a par with their fellows, not having the advantage ?ff. the extra year. But as soon as their fourth
year of residence is completed, they should automatically cease to be
eligible for Board of Control positions. , Let them gracefully yield
their place to therising college generation.
, This stand applies not only to' men who have Completed four
years at Johns Hopkins, but to those who have spent .part of their
allotted time elsewhere. Although it be unjust, it is a recognized •
fact that an upperclassman receives more consideration from the incumbents, and less difficulty in attaining a staff position than a fresh'
man. He is not compelled to, go through the long period of trial
and training to which the yearlings are subjected. Since he is given
preferential treatment as a candidate, he should accept the fact that
it will be more difficult for him to attain the, heights in his 'chosen
activity.
We do not think that thc activities will suffer greatly, if the five"
year man is prohibited from leading them. If he is a man of unusual ability he will have attained his major position in the four years
at his disposal. If he is not unusually capable there will be someone
in the senior class equally as well qualified to guide the destinies of
the activity as he.

EDITORIALS

S-LETTER, MAY 7, 1929

Pic*:
I smcfke and dream, and dream until
I get a plot, and get a thrill.
I am in the writing game, you see;
And the pipe-dreams softly bring to me
Scenes of carnage where the red blood
ran,.
And the dreams all come from a bright
Blue can.
It's just a can of Edgeworth-cutFragrant as flowers-sweet as Luut;
Of all Fate's kindly gifts to man
Is this gift of dreams from the bright
Blue can.
I sit me down at eve, to smoke;
And soon am wrapped in a magic cloak;
It has banished trouble, it has banished pain,
And the sad old world is young again.
J. H. Rockwell
Midland, Michigan.

Attempting to refute my statement that the Liberal Club has no
initiative, "Liberal Club Member"
says, "... The program of speakers
presented, the representation of
other schools and colleges, the interest and enthusiasm aroused are -evidence of the ability of the club to
act as well as discuss." 1 must confets that I do ,not quite follow this
line of reasoning. To My mind, a
conference does not imply action. It
is a discussion,- pure and simple. I
believe I could say merely simple.
In conclusion, I believe that none
of my remarks has been satisfactorily answered. May I hope that the
Liberal Club will try again
Yours sincerely,
"Ben."
